title: 1998-B
statement: B. Minimize Equal Sum Subarraystime limit per test1.5 secondsmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputIt is known thatFarmer John likes Permutations, but I like them too!— Sun Tzu,The Art of Constructing PermutationsYou are given a permutation$$$^{\\text{∗}}$$$ $$$p$$$ of length $$$n$$$.Find a permutation $$$q$$$ of length $$$n$$$ that minimizes the number of pairs ($$$i, j$$$) ($$$1 \\leq i \\leq j \\leq n$$$) such that $$$p_i + p_{i+1} + \\ldots + p_j = q_i + q_{i+1} + \\ldots + q_j$$$.$$$^{\\text{∗}}$$$A permutation of length $$$n$$$ is an array consisting of $$$n$$$ distinct integers from $$$1$$$ to $$$n$$$ in arbitrary order. For example, $$$[2,3,1,5,4]$$$ is a permutation, but $$$[1,2,2]$$$ is not a permutation ($$$2$$$ appears twice in the array), and $$$[1,3,4]$$$ is also not a permutation ($$$n=3$$$ but there is $$$4$$$ in the array).InputThe first line contains $$$t$$$ ($$$1 \\leq t \\leq 10^4$$$) — the number of test cases.The first line of each test case contains $$$n$$$ ($$$1 \\leq n \\leq 2 \\cdot 10^5$$$).The following line contains $$$n$$$ space-separated integers $$$p_1, p_2, \\ldots, p_n$$$ ($$$1 \\leq p_i \\leq n$$$) — denoting the permutation $$$p$$$ of length $$$n$$$.It is guaranteed that the sum of $$$n$$$ over all test cases does not exceed $$$2 \\cdot 10^5$$$.OutputFor each test case, output one line containing any permutation of length $$$n$$$ (the permutation $$$q$$$) such that $$$q$$$ minimizes the number of pairs.ExampleInput321 251 2 3 4 574 7 5 1 2 6 3Output2 1 3 5 4 2 1 6 2 1 4 7 3 5NoteFor the first test, there exists only one pair ($$$i, j$$$) ($$$1 \\leq i \\leq j \\leq n$$$) such that $$$p_i + p_{i+1} + \\ldots + p_j = q_i + q_{i+1} + \\ldots + q_j$$$, which is ($$$1, 2$$$). It can be proven that no such $$$q$$$ exists for which there are no pairs.

processed.result:
You are given a permutation $p$ of length $n$. Find a permutation $q$ of length $n$ that minimizes the number of pairs $(i, j)$ ($1 \leq i \leq j \leq n$) such that the sum of elements in $p$ from index $i$ to $j$ is equal to the sum of elements in $q$ from index $i$ to $j$. 

In other words, minimize the number of pairs $(i, j)$ where:

 $$p_i + p_{i+1} + ... + p_j = q_i + q_{i+1} + ... + q_j$$



**Input:**

* The first line contains $t$ ($1 \leq t \leq 10^4$) - the number of test cases.
* The first line of each test case contains $n$ ($1 \leq n \leq 2 \cdot 10^5$) - the length of the permutation.
* The following line contains $n$ space-separated integers $p_1, p_2, ..., p_n$ ($1 \leq p_i \leq n$) - the permutation $p$.

**Output:**

For each test case, output one line containing a permutation $q$ of length $n$ that minimizes the number of pairs.

You are given a list of numbers. Find a different list of the same numbers that has the fewest number of pairs of positions where the sum of the numbers in the first list between those positions equals the sum of the numbers in the second list between those same positions.
